summary.text_en: In 1684, Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz published the paper 'Nova Methodus pro Maximis et Minimis' (A New Method for Maxima and Minima, and for Tangents), the first published paper on calculus in history. Leibniz independently invented calculus alongside Newton and created the calculus notation system we use today, including the differential symbols dx, dy, and the integral symbol âˆ«. His notation was clearer and more practical than Newton's fluxion notation, and was eventually adopted worldwide.
key_points_en: Created modern calculus notation (dx, dy, âˆ«)
Notation system was clearer and more practical than Newton's

story.text_en: Leibniz had completed the basic system of calculus by 1675, but did not formally publish until 1684. His notation systemâ€”using dx to represent infinitesimal changes and âˆ« to represent summation (integration)â€”was more intuitive and easier to use than Newton's dot notation (method of fluxions). This led to the famous 'calculus priority dispute': Newton's supporters claimed Newton had invented calculus in 1665-1666 (though not published until 1704), while Leibniz's supporters pointed out that Leibniz was the first to publish. Modern historians generally agree both invented it independently, but Leibniz's notation system ultimately won out and became the standard in modern mathematics.

fun_facts.text_en: Leibniz's integral symbol âˆ« comes from an elongated form of the letter S, the first letter of the Latin word 'summa' (sum), while the differential symbol d comes from the Latin word 'differentia' (difference).

The calculus priority dispute led British mathematicians to refuse to use Leibniz's notation, insisting on Newton's fluxion notation, which caused British mathematics to lag behind continental Europe for nearly a century.

simple_explanation.text_en: Imagine you're drawing a curve and want to know how 'steep' it is at a certain point (the slope). Leibniz invented 'differentiation' to calculate this slope. Conversely, if you know the slope at each point and want to find the 'area' under the entire curve, Leibniz invented 'integration'. These two operations are inverse to each other, like addition and subtraction.

applications.text_en: Leibniz's notation system made calculus calculations more intuitive and efficient, and remains the standard today.

impact.text_en: Leibniz's calculus paper marked the beginning of modern mathematical analysis. Although he had a priority dispute with Newton, both independently invented calculus. Leibniz's notation system ultimately became the international standard, making calculus the fundamental tool for all fields of science and engineering. Without calculus, there would be no modern physics, engineering, economics, or computer science.
